evals.prompt: What should I work on next?
evals.expected_output: Reads existing PROGRESS.md, reconciles against git history, selects the highest-priority actionable item, and describes the team it would spin up to do the work

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md at root (not .claude/), defined priorities, and rich git history. Only one item in Next Up but deferred items and a known issue also exist.

expectations: Finds PROGRESS.md even though it's at the project root instead of .claude/PROGRESS.md
Checks git log to reconcile recent commits against PROGRESS.md state
Detects uncommitted changes via git status and accounts for them in its assessment
Does NOT read any source code files — only PROGRESS.md and git commands (log, status, diff, branch)
Selects a specific item to work on rather than presenting a menu of options
Explains why other candidate items were NOT selected (e.g., blocked, lower priority, dependencies)
Describes a team whose roles are clearly relevant to the selected task — not generic roles
Each proposed teammate has a detailed brief: what to do, which files to explore, success criteria
Does NOT write any code or edit any project files itself
Notes that PROGRESS.md should be moved to .claude/PROGRESS.md for SessionStart hook compatibility

evals.prompt: Pick up this project and figure out what's going on
evals.expected_output: Orients to the project by reading PROGRESS.md and git history, provides a synthesis that goes beyond restating PROGRESS.md, identifies what's actionable vs blocked

context.note: Real C++ game engine project with existing PROGRESS.md at root. Has uncommitted test files from a previous session.

expectations: Finds PROGRESS.md at the project root and uses it as the primary source of project state
Checks git log AND git status to build a complete picture of current state
Surfaces the uncommitted changes from the previous session as something that needs attention
Does NOT read any source code files — only PROGRESS.md and git commands (log, status, diff, branch)
Provides original analysis that synthesizes PROGRESS.md content rather than just restating it (e.g., connecting related items, identifying patterns, noting trajectory)
Explicitly categorizes items into actionable-now vs blocked/deferred with specific reasons for each
Does NOT write any code or edit any project files itself
Notes the PROGRESS.md path mismatch with the skill's expected .claude/ location

evals.prompt: Review the known issues section and propose a fix for the hardcoded apply_component() chain in world.cpp
evals.expected_output: Identifies the known issue from PROGRESS.md (without reading world.cpp itself), designs a team with task-specific agent personalities to explore the code and implement the fix

context.note: Known issue: World::apply_component() in world.cpp:83-204 is a hardcoded if/else chain. Project uses C++20, Flecs ECS, data-driven design.

expectations: Reads PROGRESS.md and identifies the known issue about apply_component()
Does NOT read world.cpp or any other source files — uses the known issue description from PROGRESS.md as context for the team brief
Designs a team plan (TeamCreate or describes the team it would create) that delegates BOTH exploration and implementation to teammates
Agent personalities are task-specific and relevant to a refactoring task — not generic roles like 'agent-1' or 'worker'
Teammate briefs include context from PROGRESS.md (known issue details, project patterns) and instruct teammates to explore the code themselves
The proposed team structure makes sense for the task — e.g., someone to understand the existing code, someone to implement, someone to verify
Does NOT write, edit, or modify any project source files directly
